content:
The solution used here is deceptively simple: round((2*int(input())**0.5)

It's a bit hacky because it isn't a formula that can be derived from the mathematics, which would rather be more like:
math.ceil((2*b+0.25)**0.5-0.5)

but since math.ceil(x-0.5) is almost always the same as round(x) (except where x = 0.5), you can get away with:
round((2*b)+0.25)**0.5)

and then because the +0.25 is such a small adjustment, it never makes any tangible difference in a real problem case, so you can simplify to the form used in the solution:
round((2*b)**0.5) where b = int(input()).

It's just a bit discomforting to use an approximation as the official solution, for my tastes. :P But it's very nice for Shortest mode!

Fun clash though, either way!

Comment: Nice puzzle for fastest and shortest mode

Easy to understand and come up with solution, especially if the player is familiar with the finite difference method.

The key observation is that we could find two (quadratic) equations for the starting and ending integers of each row respectively, then for any integer we could find which row it belongs to by "solving" either one of the equations (and taking either the ceiling or floor function) for the row number.

I like it. 
It would be helpful to include the number of max rows in the description in my opinion.

Nice one but needs some formatting

It's not an approximation! Although well it's not the most clear solution.
First removing the +0.25 removes the issue of round with (2*b+0.25) ** .5 = *.5.
Now you need to prove that removing the +.25
will never change the result if (2*b+0.25) ** .5 != *.5 knowing that b is an integer

Yes, like I say "because the +0.25 is such a small adjustment, it never makes any tangible difference in a real problem case", so it's an approximation that works every time, so I get why you'd argue it's not an approximation, but it still removes parts of the formula for simplification. There's nothing wrong with it, but it's just hard to reverse-engineer the logic from your code because it's hiding some of the formula.

As I said though, very nice for Shortest mode. :)
